docs.snippet: The Enron Corporation said yesterday that it had named as its president and chief operating officer Jeffrey K. Skilling, an executive who came to the company only six years ago and built up a huge business trading natural gas and electricity.    T...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Enron Corporation said yesterday that it had named as its president and chief operating officer Jeffrey K. Skilling, an executive who came to the company only six years ago and built up a huge business trading natural gas and electricity. The fact that Mr. Skilling, 43, was appointed to the No. 2 job at Enron, under Kenneth L. Lay, the chairman and chief executive, shows how quickly the trading and marketing of natural gas and electricity are growing in importance as a result of utility deregulation and how hard companies are scrambling to keep up.
docs.abstract: Enron Corp names Jeffrey K Skilling president and chief operating officer; he succeeds Richard D Kinder and will remain Enron Capital & Trade Resources unit chairman (M)

headline.main: Enron Names Trading Chief As President of Company

docs.snippet: Beneath the rolling grasslands of southern Mozambique lies a huge reserve of  natural gas, which if piped to neighboring South Africa, could bring $100 million a year in hard currency to Mozambique, the poorest country in the world.         And la...
docs.lead_paragraph: Beneath the rolling grasslands of southern Mozambique lies a huge reserve of natural gas, which if piped to neighboring South Africa, could bring $100 million a year in hard currency to Mozambique, the poorest country in the world. And last month, an aggressive American gas company, the Enron Corporation of Houston, triumphed over several competitors and signed an agreement with the Mozambique Government to develop the field.

headline.main: Enron Goes to Africa Seeking Gas and Customers

headline.main: Enron Is Resuming Arbitration on Plant

docs.snippet: The Enron Corporation, the diversified natural-gas company, said rising prices and demand for gas bolstered its first-quarter profits.   Enron's gas marketing unit, Enron Gas Services, reported a 43.8 percent gain in operating profits, to $48.6 mi...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Enron Corporation, the diversified natural-gas company, said rising prices and demand for gas bolstered its first-quarter profits. Enron's gas marketing unit, Enron Gas Services, reported a 43.8 percent gain in operating profits, to $48.6 million during the quarter. Operating income at Enron Oil and Gas rose 54.7 percent, to $31.4 million. Gas pipelines, the company's biggest unit, posted a 30.8 percent increase in pretax profits, to $144.7 million.

docs.snippet: If natural gas ever had a chance to move closer to center stage in supplying the nation's energy needs, the time is now. The war in the Persian Gulf exposed anew America's vulnerability to imported oil. Five years after Chernobyl, nuclear power is...
docs.lead_paragraph: If natural gas ever had a chance to move closer to center stage in supplying the nation's energy needs, the time is now. The war in the Persian Gulf exposed anew America's vulnerability to imported oil. Five years after Chernobyl, nuclear power is still shunned. And global warming has further darkened the cloud over coal. Cleaner and cheaper than oil, natural gas has become the favored fuel among manufacturers and power generators -- but only ideologically. Despite reserves in the United States and Canada that could last 50 years or more, gas has taken a back seat to oil, supplying only 23 percent of its fuel needs in 1989. A tangle of regulations has choked demand, produced shortages and kept prices low and most gas producers too small to vie for lucrative long-term industrial contracts. And unless it can overcome its reputation as an unreliable long-term fuel source, the gas industry will blow the nation's best chance for clearer skies, lower fuel bills and fewer geopolitical scares in the future.
